[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HAWKER CENTRES


    1. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for the Environment if his Ministry will consider building more hawker centres to enable those with insufficient capital to start their own business or who have difficulty in getting jobs due to the present economic recession to earn a living as hawkers.

Column: 874



     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    The Government started building hawker centres in 1971 for the specific purpose of relocating about 18,000 street hawkers. Hawker licences were also issued to those in financial hardship under the hardship scheme. The programme of resiting street hawkers has largely been completed. Having achieved the social and environmental objectives of providing proper

Column: 875

hawker centres for the itinerant street hawkers to operate from, the Government has decided not to build any more hawker centres and to let the private sector cater for such business in future.

    I wish to remind hon. Members that having a stall in a hawker centre is not an assured means of livelihood as the competition for consumers today has become very keen. In today's context, hawkers operating in hawker centres require business acumen and culinary skills. Those in financial hardship are aware of the risk involved and many do not take up stalls even if they are allocated stalls after having satisfied the means test. For example, over the last five years, only 162 of the 922 cases who qualified or 18% took up stalls. Of the 162 who took up stalls, subsequently 40, or 25%, gave up their stalls within a few months.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, could the Parliamentary Secretary tell the House the number of itinerant hawkers at present? My second question is: will the Hawkers Department consider raising the upper age limit of 60 so that those who are above 60 and are still healthy but jobless can still apply for a hawker licence?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I do not have the exact figures of itinerant hawkers with me, but there are very, very few left. Most of them have been resited in hawker centres and markets and sundry stalls.

    With regard to the age limit, the proposal is an interesting one. But the important thing really is how fit the person is medically. So if the Member for Delta has any case where he feels that a person of 60 years or more wishes to apply for a hawker licence, we will consider him if he can pass the medical test.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok: Sir, in his answer just now, he said that hardship is the only criterion for applying for a hawker licence. Will the Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider, in addition to hardship case, culinary skills to be another criterion for applying for a hawker licence?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I think that is a very good idea. Culinary skills are, in fact, a more important criterion than hardship because, more often than not,

Column: 876

you find that among those hardship cases who are given licences, most do not make it a success but some do. Sometimes giving them a licence is to do them more harm than good. So if a person has the culinary skill, I think it is worthwhile considering. In fact, now that we have completed our programme of resiting street hawkers into proper hawker centres, it may be about time to reconsider the criteria for issue of hawker licences. That will take some time though.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, of the 922 cases, most of whom rejected the stalls offered to them, to what extent was location a factor? We know very well that certain hawker centres are popular. The applicants too know this very well. And very often the vacant stalls that are offered are those in locations which are very unfavourable for business.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, again I do not have the exact figures with me so I cannot tell him how many of the 922 cases were rejected because of location. But I think the Member has a point there. We all have the impression that the success of a hawker depends on either the location of the hawker centre or location from his own house. I presume the Member for Whampoa is talking about the location of the hawker centre in respect of clientele. Am I correct? Or location from home?

     Dr Augustine Tan: Clientele.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: On clientele. I have been told, Mr Speaker, Sir, that there are hawker centres in Tuas, Punggol Point, even in one of the islands, Pulau Ubin, if I am not mistaken, where Singaporeans flock to for their food. That brings up the point of the Member for Delta where culinary skills do indeed play a part in attracting clientele to the hawker centres, and not totally dependant on location.

     Mr Lim Boon Heng (Kebun Baru): Sir, can the Senior Parliamentary Secretary tell us what is the rate of hawkers who give up their stalls for all hawkers, rather than just for the new cases that were granted? Could he give us an approximate figure or percentage of those who are giving up their trade as hawkers?

Column: 877



     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: If the Member for Kebun Baru could frame another question for Oral Answer, I would be too willing to give it to him.

     Mr Bernard Chen (Clementi): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Hon. Senior Parliamentary Secretary inform the House that among those who rejected the allocation of stalls, what is the proportion of cooked food stalls to market produce stalls? As I understand it, most of the rejections were for the market produce stalls, while cooked food stalls seem to draw quite a high percentage of acceptance.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Maybe when the Member for Kebun Baru frames his question, we can consider this question together. But off hand, if I can say so, I think the Member for Clementi is correct in saying that there are more people who reject market produce stalls than for cooked food stalls.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Hon. Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider upgrading existing hawker centres so that business can be improved, for example, the addition of suitable car parking facilities? Secondly, Sir, in the event that any hawker centre is to be demolished, an alternative of a more suitable site should be provided, such as a site close by or nearby in order to safeguard the livelihood of the stallholders?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, am I to presume that all hawker centres have the same date of relocation? I do not think so. I presume the Member is referring to his own hawker centre.

     Dr Augustine Tan: I do have in mind one hawker centre at Jalan Tenteram in my constituency. But this question is of interest to more than just Jalan Tenteram Hawker Centre.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will ask my officers to look into this idea or opinion, and we will deal with it accordingly.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, my question is: what does the Hon. Parliamentary Secretary think of my idea? I am not interested in what his officials think.

Column: 878



     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, when I get the details of the report from my officers, I will give him my opinion.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Senior Hon. Parliamentary Secretary not agree with me that the principle of the matter is clear enough for anybody to see and that he can commit himself if he wants to?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know what principle we are talking here. But the important thing is yes, I agree that generally there should be a car park somewhere near a hawker centre. There should be easy access to the hawker centre. But without the details of his question, it is very difficult for me to agree with a general statement of that sort.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, would he agree with me that relocation will cause considerable hardship to hawkers who have to be dispersed, relocated in different locations far away from their homes when they already have a comfortable means of livelihood close by so that, when their existing stalls are demolished, it would be in their interest to have an alternative source of livelihood close by their homes?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I presume it is also in the interest of the Member for Whampoa to have these hawkers relocated in his own constituency rather than, for example, move out of their homes. But there is a provision whereby if a hawker moves home and his hawker stall is too far away for him to commute, then he can always ask if we could help, and we do help.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Hon. Senior Parliamentary Secretary answer my question specifically, namely, that if an existing hawker centre is to be demolished, provision should be made to allow for another hawker centre to be established?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I think that would come under the province of the Ministry of National Development because they are the ones who do the town planning.

Column: 879



     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Hon. Senior Parliamentary Secretary support, in principle, what I am advocating here, so that we can push the idea with the Ministry for National Development?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: It is a good idea. I will support you.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two supplementary questions for the Parliamentary Secretary. First, is he in a position to tell us what is the vacancy rate, that is, the percentage of stalls that are vacant in food hawker centres? Secondly, has his Ministry stopped issuing licences for itinerant hawkers? If so, will the Ministry consider issuing licences for itinerant hawkers in at least some special cases?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, first question on the vacancy rate. I do not have the exact figures but the vacancy rate can range from, say, 4% in a rather healthy market - when I say "healthy", I mean the amount of business - to about 30% in a rather sluggish one. On the other question, yes, we have stopped issuing licences for itinerant hawkers. By "itinerant", do you mean moving from place to place?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I cannot think of any special case where we can give licences to itinerant hawkers.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong (Paya Lebar): Sir, will the Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider licences for itinerant hawkers using vans if environment measures can be controlled?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I think there are some delivery vans that bring provisions to homes. Is that what you mean?

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: That is not what I meant. What I meant was: will you consider allowing people to do itinerant hawking by using vans if environment measures can be controlled?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: That is a very general proposition. But I do not really know what the Member means when he says "environmental problems

Column: 880

can be controlled." I say that, in general, we discourage street hawking in any form, whether it be in a van, on a bicycle or on two legs.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary recognize that if a person takes, for example, dry goods in a van and moves around from estate to estate, there is really no problem as regards pollution or environmental health?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: If pollution and environmental health hazards are the only problems we are worried about, so be it. But there are problems more than just pollution.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: What are they?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Traffic congestion, for instance. Basically, if you are talking about a goods delivery van, we do not control those operators. But if the operator of the van carries goods and stops here and there to sell his goods, then we have to control them.

Column: 880

APPLICATION FOR HAWKER LICENCES
(Priority for old retrenched workers)


    2. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for the Environment whether he will give priority to applicants for hawker licences who have been retrenched and are unable to find new jobs because of old age.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid that no priority will be given to retrenched persons applying for a hawker licence because not all retrenched persons are in financial hardship. To qualify for a hawker licence, a means test, based on the applicant's financial position, age and the number of dependants he has to support, is imposed. As long as the applicant satisfies the hardship criteria, he can choose from available vacancies in the hawker centres. Over January and February this year, 14 of the 68 approved cases, or 21%, were retrenched persons.

    However, I must inform the Member for Telok Blangah that since the Government is not building any more hawker centres,

Column: 881

vacancies in HDB and MOE hawker centres are very limited indeed.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am concerned about the failure rate of 25%. Do the Ministry officials offer advice to applicants on the capital cost for setting up a hawker stall, so that they will know what potential risks they are incurring? This is to discourage applicants who have no skills but want to take up a stall.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I would think that these people can probably get better help from their friends or those who are already operating stalls to let them know the cost of starting a hawking business.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok: Sir, will the Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider converting vacant stalls in a produce market into cooked food stalls?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Yes. In fact, we have already been carrying out conversion exercises. But there are some stalls you can convert and others you cannot.

     Mr Speaker: Dr Koh.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, before I ask Questions 3 and 4, I would like to declare my pecuniary interest in these two questions. Question 3, Sir.

Column: 881

MATERNITY LEAVE FOR THIRD CHILD DELIVERY


    3. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for Finance whether he will consider granting maternity leave to female employees in the civil service and statutory boards who are expecting their third child.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is weighing the implications of granting leave to female officers in the civil service for their third child. An Inter-Ministerial Committee on Population considers it urgent that we review the very low reproduction rates of women with three 'O' levels and above. Because of the high singles rate and the late age of marriage of

Column: 882

such women, they have an average reproduction rate of only 1.3 children per woman. This is well below the replacement rate of 2.05 children per woman.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, would the Minister consider granting maternity leave to a woman employee who is expecting a third child but in her second pregnancy? In other words, she had twins in her first pregnancy. Will she be entitled to maternity leave for her second pregnancy?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the question is a little complex for me to answer. I will ask my officials to study it.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, the point I am trying to make is that the duration of maternity leave should be related to the number of pregnancies and not to the number of living children. For example, a woman can have triplets in her first pregnancy.

     Mr Speaker: There is no need to explain. What is your supplementary question, Dr Koh?

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Would the Minister agree that the duration of maternity leave given to a woman employee should be related to the number of pregnancies? If you give two periods of maternity leave per employee during her term of employment, then it should be related to the number of pregnancies.

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said earlier, we will study this problem.

Column: 882

MEDISAVE ACCOUNTS
(Withdrawal for Third child delivery expenses)


    4. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider allowing expectant mothers to withdraw moneys from Medisave accounts to defray hospital expenses for the delivery of a third or subsequent child.

     The Minister of State for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will answer on behalf of my Minister.

Column: 883



    Currently, Medisave accounts may be used in Government hospitals for the hospitalization expenses incurred in third or higher order births for highly educated mothers.

    The Ministry is currently reviewing this Scheme with the objective of allowing the use of Medisave for high order births on the basis of the affordability of the parents to properly support and raise a large family, rather than on the educational qualification of the mother. This will be in line with Government's policy to help the lower-income group break out of the poverty trap by having smaller families.

    The review will be completed within the next six months.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the the Minister for State by what right does his Ministry take it upon itself to consider the affordability of parents to have a third child or more?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, population policy is the responsibility of the Government as a whole. The Government has been analysing the procreation figures and the results of the lopsided procreation pattern have been well noted and well publicized. It is in the interest of the nation that this lopsided pattern be corrected and therefore the Medisave policy for higher order births was propounded and implemented as part of the national effort to remedy this lopsided policy. Based on the results to date, the Ministry has found that this policy of allowing Medisave only for the highly educated mothers has not produced the desired results. Therefore, we are in the process of reviewing it in order to broaden the policy but without jeopardizing the chances of people in the lower-income group of getting out of their present poverty trap.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister of State concede quite frankly and candidly that this policy, like everything else, is a thoroughly discriminatory measure against the poor and the lower educated?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: It is not a discriminatory measure. If a family can afford to bring up their children, provide the

Column: 884

children with proper education, proper upbringing -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: What about children's allowances? Why do you not give them something?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: - to ensure that they will grow up with the proper training, proper education, so that they can contribute meaningfully to the growth of our country, they will be encouraged, in fact, to have larger families.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, in what way does the Minister of State think that, by allowing the release of Medisave funds to defray hospital expenses for the delivery of the third child, this will actually help to correct the pattern of lopsided procreation ? Or does it make it worse?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: It will help to correct the pattern if the target group finds that it is a useful benefit. But at the same time, we have to be sure that those in the lower-income group are not enticed by this liberalization into having more children, thereby jeopardizing their own chances of helping the family get out of their present predicament.

Column: 884

CLOSURE OF MEDISAVE ACCOUNT FOR THE ELDERLY


    5. Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong asked the Minister for Health, in view of the fact that a Central Provident Fund member can utilize his Medisave account for the payment of medical bills of his parents and grandparents, whether he will consider (i) allowing an elderly person with children and/or grandchildren to withdraw all his moneys from his Medisave account, and (ii) exempting an elderly worker from contributing to his Medisave account even if he has less than $15,000.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, a person reaching the age of 55 before the end of this month will only need to retain in his Medisave account a sum of $5,500 or his actual Medisave balance, whichever is the lower. He can withdraw the amount in excess of this $5,500.

    It has been established that an average person can expect to be hospitalized a

Column: 885

total of 59 days from the age of 55 to the time he dies. The bulk of these hospitalization days will be during the last six months of his life. This amount retained in the Medisave account will allow the elderly to look after their own hospitalization needs, and that of their spouse, thereby reducing the financial pressure on their children or grandchildren.

    A Medisave account holder who continues working after the age of 55 will also continue his Medisave contributions. The amount in excess of the prevailing Medisave limit may be withdrawn once in every three years.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, will the Minister of State consider that if the children are willing to defray the medical costs of their parents or grandparents, will the elderly person be allowed to withdraw all his funds?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, where the elderly have the means to support their own hospitalization needs, we should encourage them to do so without burdening their children, without increasing the financial pressure on their children. The amount at the moment retained in the Medisave balance of the elderly, ie, those people above 55 years old, is only $5,500. This will increase to $6,000 from 1st April. This amount, I can assure the House, will be barely adequate to look after his own hospitalization needs as well as that of his wife.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, will the Minister of State not agree that if an elderly person has a house of his own, and when he passes away, the house will be bequeathed to the children or grandchildren? If that is the case, the children or grandchildren will benefit from the death of this elderly person. Is it not right for the elderly person now to enjoy the fruits of his labour while he is alive?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if it is the objective of every parent to leave the minimum to his children when he dies, then I think we would have many of the elderly selling their house by the time they reach 55 years and take up rented accom-

Column: 886

modation so that they can enjoy the fruits of their investment.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Does not the Minister of State agree with me that if the children of an elderly person have adequate or more than adequate funds in their Medisave and are willing to use those funds for this elderly person, and furthermore they are ready to give a written undertaking to that effect, then should he not therefore allow the elderly person to withdraw his or her own Medisave funds?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it is important for us to get the aim of the Medisave Scheme in the right perspective. The aim of the Medisave Scheme is to ensure that every one has adequate funds to look after primarily his own hospitalization needs and his immediate dependants' needs. If his parents do have the ability, through their own Medisave funds, to look after their hospitalization needs, I think it is important for the parents to continue using their own funds, and relying on the children only when their own Medisave balances are used up. This will ensure that their children will, in turn, have adequate funds of their own because they must inevitably also reach the age of 55.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it not the greater aim to prevent the dependence upon the people at large, through taxation or increased taxation, to bear the cost of medical bills? But if the children of an elderly person have adequate Medisave funds and they are still relatively young and have future earnings to come and future balances to build up in their Medisave accounts, surely the Minister of State should consider favourably this particular request. And surely also he should consider the fact that while many old people under the present scheme will have adequate money in their Medisave accounts to finance the last few months of their lives here on earth, but at the same time they will be miserable and without food for the last few years of their lives.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, if the children have more than adequate Medisave balances, their excess will be paid into their Ordinary CPF account, thereby allowing it to be used for their own housing or investment needs. The

Column: 887

children, if they are that well off, can easily provide for the daily needs of the parents, if that is the case. It is important for us to ensure that the elderly are able to look after themselves because in the years to come there will be a large number of elderly amongst us. As we have seen in the United States and in the United Kingdom and the other developed countries, the plight of the elderly is fairly serious. In fact, there was an article in the Newsweek magazine last week that highlighted the inability of the elderly in the US to afford proper medical care because of lack of funds. I think it is important for us to bear that in mind and to ensure that we do not get into that same situation in the next 20 or 30 years.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, another supplementary question for the Minister of State about the aim of the Medisave. Will the Minister of State again quite candidly concede that one of the principal aims of Medisave was to ensure that Government would be able to recover the cost of medical treatment? Is he aware that very recently the Attorney-General has written a letter to a man who owes the hospital something like $300 and who is at present out of employment, threatening to bring proceedings if he did not pay up the $300?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, at the present moment our medical services are very, very heavily subsidized. If it is the intention of the Government, as it is, to reduce taxation and reduce the burden on business and on wage earners, then it is important that we are able to reduce these subsidies in years to come. However, whilst we are reducing the subsidies, the Government will still ensure, as I have stated many times in this Chamber, that the indigent and those who are unable to pay will still be given the appropriate level of medical care. That consideration must always be there. There is nothing wrong with the Government reducing the subsidy because the subsidy is still there and it is going to be still very substantial.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Question No. 6, Sir.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask another supplementary question?

MEDISAVE ACCOUNTS
(Common limit for couples)


    6. Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider exempting a working spouse from contributing to his or her Medisave account if the combined balance in the working couple's Medisave accounts is $15,000 so as to allow more money for the repayment of a housing loan.

    9. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Health whether he will allow the Central Provident Fund Medisave accounts of a married couple to be considered jointly so that when their combined Medisave savings exceed $15,000, the balance can be transferred to their CPF ordinary accounts for use towards repayment of any housing loan.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, since Question No. 9 is also on the same topic, may I have your permission to answer both questions at the same time.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has already announced a number of measures to assist house owners who are unable to service their housing loan repayments because of the scheduled reduction in employer's CPF contributions. There is therefore no need to consider exempting a working spouse from contributing to her Medisave Account.

Column: 888

MARKET DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE SCHEME
(Particulars)

The ability to think, to show initiative and to work independently are important if this country really wants to progress. These words, in their present-day context, when translated into the real situation would mean something like this: give plenty of tuition to a child, get him to score eight or nine straight A's in '0' level and another five A's in 'A' level if possible, and get him to study very hard at the University and come out with a good Honours degree or, better still, a Ph.D. Then he would be considered to be in the top 5% of our society and highly qualified for a ministerial post. the Prime Minister makes sure that his son attended that University. It is only under a more liberal and democratic environment where its students are encouraged to think, to ask questions without fear and to show initiative that students can eventually be leaders. We also need to educate all our children to think - I think that is very important - to solve problems, to show initiative and to be able to work independently without somebody telling him all the time what to do.

    So the issue really is what type of education system do we want. Do we want a more liberal, democratic type of education system?
